A '''sunshine list''' is a listing of salary, benefit and severance information.<ref name="calgarysun.com">[http://www.calgarysun.com/2014/03/20/alberta-premier-alison-redford-leaves-mixed-legacy-behind "Alberta Premier Alison Redford Leaves Mixed Legacy Behind]</ref> In Canada, the list is commonly used for example by provincial or municipal governments to identify any publicly employed person making $100,000 salary or higher.<ref name="cbc.ca">[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/sunshine-list-2014-ontario-s-top-public-earners-list-released-1.2590152 CBC News "Sunshine List 2014: Ontario's Top Public Earners List Released"]</ref> The purpose of the list is to provide accountability and transparency, requiring "organizations that receive public funding from the Province of Ontario to disclose annually the names, positions, salaries and total taxable benefits of employees paid $100,000 or more in a calendar year."<ref>[http://www.fin.gov.on.ca/en/publications/salarydisclosure/pssd/ Government of Ottawa Salary Disclosure Act]</ref>
==History==
===Alberta=== Alberta first started publishing a sunshine list in 2014 following the 2012 election of [[Alison Redford]]. The introduction of the list followed public debate about the severance awarded to Redford's former chief of staff.<ref name="calgarysun.com"/> In Alberta, the policy applies to deputy ministers, senior officials, political staff appointed under the Executive Assistant Order and employees defined under the Public Service Act who work for the offices of ministers and associate ministers, and who make an annual base salary of at least $100,000. The government began disclosing base salaries, benefit and severance amounts, and details of contract and termination agreements beginning on 31 January 2014. Information was to be posted online twice annually no later than 30 June and 31 December and included all staff employed as of 23 April 2012.<ref>[https://archive.is/20140819012327/http://www.ffwdweekly.com/article/news-views/news/sunshine-list-11654/ FFWD weekly article]</ref>
===Ontario=== Ontario introduced the sunshine list in 1996 under the [[Mike Harris]] government.<ref name="cbc.ca"/>
==Uses== While intended as an accountability tool, the lists have been used for other purposes. ''[[Maclean's]]'' magazine, for example, has used the list to examine employment equity in academia.<ref>[http://www.macleans.ca/education/uniandcollege/knocking-on-the-glass-ceiling/ "Knocking on the Glass Ceiling"]</ref>
==Flaw== In 2011, Chris Mazza, President and CEO of [[Ornge]], managed to stay off the sunshine list while making $1.4 million per year in a controversial scandal.<ref name="Star22Dec11">{{Cite news|url = https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/1105806--ornge-president-was-paid-1-4-million-per-year|title = ORNGE president was paid $1.4 million per year|accessdate = 2 February 2012|last = Donovan|first = Kevin|date = 22 December 2011| work = [[Toronto Star]]}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== [https://www.sunshineliststats.com Search the Ontario sunshine list]

{{Multiple issues| {{Essay-like|date=April 2015}} {{howto|date=April 2015}} }}
'''Sweatshop-free''' or '''sweat free'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sweatfree.org/shoppingguide|title=SweatFree Communities: Shop with a Conscience Consumer Guide|work=Sweatfree.org|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenamerica.org/livinggreen/nosweatshops.cfm |title=Living Green: Sweatshop-Free Clothing |publisher=Greenamerica.org |date= |accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oxfam.org.au/explore/workers-rights/are-your-clothes-made-in-sweatshops/|title=Are your clothes made in sweatshops? - Oxfam Australia|work=Oxfam Australia|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treehugger.com/tag/sweatshop-free/|title=Sweatshop-Free : TreeHugger|work=treehugger.com}}</ref> is a term first used by [[American Apparel]],<ref name="americanapparel.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.americanapparel.net/aboutus/verticalint/workers/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610043456/http://www.americanapparel.net/aboutus/verticalint/workers/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-06-10|title=American Apparel - Fashionable Basics. Sweatshop Free. Made in USA.|work=Americanapparel.ne|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> a famous American clothing brand, which means coercion-free, fair-compensation for the garment workers who manufacture their products. The aim of sweatshop-free wish to ensure that all employees are treated fairly and products are made in good working conditions. Sweatshop-free standards include the right to collective bargaining, non-poverty wages, safe workplaces, back wages, and non-harassment. It has been heavily featured in American Apparel’s advertisements and become a common term in the garment industry.[[File:Sweatshopfree.jpg|thumb|right]]
==Versus sweatshop==
===Sweatshop=== A sweatshop is a factory or workplace, especially in the garment industry, where workers are employed at very low wages for long hours and under poor working conditions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8jOaTCNNtbIC&pg=PA1&dq=sweatshop&hl=zh-TW&sa=X&ei=93FTVMy0BY_g7QbshoH4Dg&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=sweatshop&f=false|title=Making Sweatshops|work=Google.co.uk|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref>
Many sweatshop factories in developing countries such as India, China, Cambodia, Indonesia, Vietnam, Bangladesh employ low-pay worker or even child labour around 10–14 years old to work in their factories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.harvard.edu/programs/lwp/NLC_childlabor.html|title=Children Found Sewing Clothing For Wal-Mart, Hanes & Other U.S. & European Companies - National Labor Committee|work=Harvard.edu|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> These workers are forced to work up to 16 hours a day seven days a week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waronwant.org/overseas-work/sweatshops-and-plantations/sweatshops-in-bangladesh|title=Sweatshops in Bangladesh|work=War On Want|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> They do not receive any basic employee benefits such as health care, maternity leave, sick pay and holiday pay from their employers. They sometime make the female workers to take birth control and take regular pregnancy test to stop maternity leave. And these workers only earn 25p an hour<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waronwant.org/overseas-work/sweatshops-and-plantations/china-sweatshops|title=Sweatshops in China|work=War On Want|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> which is much lower than the legal national [[minimum wage]]. Even labours work long hours everyday, their salaries are usually just enough to cover their basic living cost.
Besides, sweatshop factories usually have harsh working conditions.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/05/business/worldbusiness/05sweatshop.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1& |title=In Chinese Factories, Lost Fingers and Low Pay |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> For example, no rest break, no air-conditioning and workers have to stand for their entire shift. Some workers even had to work in unsafe and hazardous conditions which may causes working injuries or even fatal factory incidents. Take China as an example, in 2009 alone, approximately one million workers were injured at work and about 20,000 suffered from diseases due to their occupation. The reason for this is that the sweatshop factories did not provide any safety guidance for their employees. Lots of sweatshop workers are also suffering from labour abuse, sexual harassment and discrimination in their workplaces. To avoid labours organising protests or any campaign against unfair labour practise, many sweatshop factories find ways to prevent the establishment of the trade unions.
===Sweatshop-free=== In sweatshop, labours have to work for long hours but receive very low salary which is only half or even less than the legal [[minimum wage]] under a harsh working condition. The aim of sweatshop-free wish to ensure that all employees are treated fairly and products are made in good working conditions. Sweatshop-free standards include the right to collective bargaining, non-poverty wages, safe workplaces, back wages, and non-harassment.
Take American Apparel as an example, they provide all employees and their families lots of employee benefits including health insurance, parking, subsidised public transport, subsidised lunches, free on site massages, a bike lending program, a program of paid days off as well as opening an onside medical clinic for their employees.<ref name="americanapparel.net"/> American Apparel make sure that their workers are treated fairly and working in a good working conditions. They pay average skilled-sewers 25,000 US dollar per year and 12 US dollar per hour<ref name="americanapparel.net"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1C73D94TwNYC&pg=PA231&dq=sweatshop+free&hl=zh-TW&sa=X&ei=IWZTVOeiFsOu7AbSzYCwBw&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=sweatshop%20free&f=false|title=Fashion Brands|work=Google.co.uk|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> that twice the national [[minimum wage]], which is in big contrast to 25p per hour wage commonly found in sweatshop factories abroad.
===Sweatshop-free clothing=== There are a few ways to know that you are buying sweatshop-free clothing: * Look at the garment label. For example, Unite is an international union which makes sweatshop free clothing. * Many organisations, for example Green America, publish ethical consumer guides which list their recommendations for sources of sweatshop free clothing. * The price of sweatshop-free clothing is relatively higher than sweatshop products.
==Sweatshop scandals==
===Apple Inc.=== [[File:Applefactory.jpg|thumb|right| Workers in a China Apple factory. An investigation found some workers had to work 15 hours a day for £27 a month]] [[File:Iphonee5ss.jpg|thumb|right|The "S" is for Sweatshop]] [[Apple Inc]] the world's most valuable technology multinational corporation has been accused that their contractors are forcing workers to do overtime involuntarily at sweatshop working conditions and employing underage workers in its factories. Some labourers are forced to work 24 hours at a time and others are forced to stand for their entire shift. And some workers even had to work at unsafe and hazardous condition. In December 2011, 61 workers in the Riteng Computer Accessory Co factory were injured in a gas explosion whilst trialling aluminium iPad 2 back panels.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2103798/Revealed-Inside-Apples-Chinese-sweatshop-factory-workers-paid-just-1-12-hour.html|title=Revealed: Inside Apple's Chinese 'sweatshop' factory where workers are paid just £1.12 per hour|work=Mail Online|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> Due to the pressurised working conditions, in 2009, 18 workers who work in Foxconn factory, one of the Apple manufacturer, committed suicide after losing an iPhone prototype.<ref name="dailymail.co.uk"/> Over next two years, at least 18 other Apple workers try to commit suicide. Besides, undercover Inspectors have been monitoring Pegatron factory, one of the Apple contractor in Taiwan, for five months and found Apple supplier broke 86 laws and regulations<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/markets/article-2381182/Apple-accused-sweatshop-conditions-Far-Eastern-factories.html|title=Apple accused of sweatshop conditions at Far-Eastern factories - This is Money|work=This is Money|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> including workers are forced to work up to 70 hours per week as well as hiring more than 100,000 underage labour to work on the production lines. These sweatshop scandals strongly affected the reputation of the company.
[[File:Portestorr.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters stand outside the Primark shop on Oxford St with SWEATSHOP SHAME banner]]
===Primark=== [[Primark]], a leading high street fashion chain, has been blamed that three of its Indian suppliers are using child labour in their factories. After BBC Panorama’s six months undercover investigation, they discovered the Indian suppliers were sub-contracting middlemen who employed children at Bhavanisagar refugee camp. Investigators found a 9-year-old boy who is working in the refugee camp sweatshop “Sometimes we get major orders in and we have to work double quick. I get paid a few rupees for finishing each garment, but in a good day I can make 40 rupees (60p)” and “The beads we sew are very small and when we work late at night we have to work by candle - the electricity in the camp is poor.” <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/exposed-primarks-sweatshops-that-pay-children-just-60p-a-day-6875294.html|title=Exposed: Primark's sweatshops that pay children just 60p a day|work=The Evening Standard|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> Primark sub-contractors hired young children to work under poor working conditions, paying them as little as 13p an hour and they have to work up to 48 hours a week. After BBC Panorama investigation discovered that the Indian suppliers had used child labour to carry out embroidery and sequin work, Primark then fired the Indian suppliers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/7824291.stm|title=BBC News - Primark linked to UK sweatshops|work=Bbc.co.uk|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref>
BBC also reported that TNS Knitwear,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nosweat.org.uk/story/2009/01/12/primark-clothes-made-sweatshop-labour-uk-factory|title=Primark: clothes made by sweatshop labour in UK factory|work=Nosweat.org.uk|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> a Manchester-based supplier that provide Primark with about 20,000 garment a week, was not only employing illegal immigrants from Pakistan, Afghanistan and India, but also paying them as little as £3 per hour<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/news/872736/primark-linked-manchester-sweatshop/ |title=Primark linked with Manchester sweatshop |publisher=Managementtoday.co.uk |date=2009-01-12 |accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> which is well below than the legal [[minimum wage]] but the company has denied all the allegations.
==Sweatshop-free legislation and activism== In October 2008, the City of Portland, Oregon passed the "City of Portland Sweatshop Free Procuremenat Policy” <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portlandonline.com/auditor/index.cfm?c=26882&a=264837|title=ADM-1.17 - Sweatshop Free Procurement Policy Administrative Rules|date=30 January 2013|work=Portlandonline.com|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> which is the pacific northwest’s first city to adopt this policy. Portland Sweatshop-Free Purchasing Policy requires the local apparel manufacturers to guarantee their garments were produced in workplaces free of sweatshop conditions. Local apparel manufacturers have to disclose their manufacturing facility locations and meet ethical souring practices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2008/10/20/newscolumn1.html?page=all|title=Portland city officials adopt sweatshop-free policy|work=Portland Business Journal|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> Apart from monitoring the local apparel manufacturers, the city also participate and collaborate with public agencies and other non- profit organisation to promote sweatshop free procurement practices <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portlandonline.com/auditor/index.cfm?c=26882&a=218021|title=ADM-1.16 - Sweatshop Free Procurement Policy and Code of Conduct for Apparel Contractors|date=30 January 2013|work=Portlandonline.com|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> which is institutionalizing meaningful change. A not-for-profit organisation called SweatsHope <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sweatshope.org|title=SweatsHope|work=SweatsHope.org|accessdate=2015-04-07}}</ref> aims to produce ethical factories in Kolkata, India to stop human trafficking (women and children), we also aim to create an ethical place of work for the victims of abuse, freeing them from sex trade. This workplace will become a place of refuge, education, childcare and provide a decent wage. They believe Shutting down one sweatshop, will only create less jobs for people who are already struggling with employment, or that another sweatshop will just open up next door. Retailers are always trying to get cheaper manufacturing costs, this is why we need to stand up and demand ethical treatment and wages for staff. If the consumers demand this, and demand an ‘open book’ of their suppliers, we will create a sweatshop free world.

page.title: The Nature of the Judicial Process

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Nature of the Judicial Process | image = | caption = | author = [[Benjamin N. Cardozo]] | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language =English | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Yale University Press]] | pub_date = 1921 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Nature of the Judicial Process''''' is a legal classic written by [[Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court]], and [[New York Court of Appeals]] [[Chief Justice]] [[Benjamin N. Cardozo]] in 1921. It was compiled from [[The Storrs Lectures]] delivered at [[Yale Law School]] earlier that year.
==Summary==
The central question of ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'' is how judges should decide cases. Cardozo’s answer is that judges should do what they have always done in the Anglo-American legal tradition, namely, follow and apply the law in easy cases, and make new law in hard cases by balancing competing considerations, including the paramount value of social welfare. Cardozo identifies four leading methods of legal analysis: (1) the method of logic (or “analogy,” or “philosophy”), which seeks to extend legal principles in ways that preserve logical consistency; (2) the method of history (or “evolution”), which adverts to the historical origins of the legal rule or concept; (3) the method of custom (or “tradition”), which views social customs as helpful guides to community values and settled expectations; and (4) the method of sociology, which looks to considerations of reason, justice, utility, and social welfare.<ref>Benjamin N. Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process''. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1921, pp. 30-31.</ref> Each of these methods may have their “preponderating value”<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', p. 67.</ref> in particular cases. No simple test or rigid formula can decide which method should prevail in a given case.<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', p. 36.</ref> But in difficult cases where a legal rule is outmoded or the law contains “gaps” that must be filled, judges should frankly play the role of legislators and let “the welfare of society fix the path.”<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', p. 67.</ref>
Cardozo admits that there are risks in judicial lawmaking. To minimize these, he points to a number of factors that significantly limit judicial discretion. First, judges may make new law only “interstitially,” that is, when the law contains gaps or a legal rule is clearly obsolete.<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', p. 113.</ref> Second, judges in their exercise of judicial review should never strike down a law unless it is “so plainly arbitrary and oppressive that right-minded men and women could not reasonably regard”<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', p. 91.</ref> it otherwise. Finally, when judges invoke norms such as “reason,” “justice,” or “social advantage” when employing the method of sociology, they should look to community standards rather than to their own personal values.<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', p. 89</ref> In the Anglo-American system of law, Cardozo remarks, a judge “is not a knight-errant, roaming at will in pursuit of his own ideal of beauty or of goodness.”<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', p. 141.</ref> In the final balance, a judge’s freedom to innovate is insignificant “compared with the bulk and pressure of the rules that hedge him on every side.”<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', pp. 136-37.</ref>
In claiming that judges do and must make law, Cardozo was siding with [[Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr.]], [[Roscoe Pound]], [[John Chipman Gray]], and other American “proto-realists” of his day who were challenging the traditional “oracular” or “mechanical” or “formalist” view of judicial reasoning. On that view, judges never make law, they simply discover pre-existing law and apply it. According to strict formalists, there are no hard cases where the law is silent, or ambiguous, or vague, or contradictory, or couched in broad generalities. Rather, the law is clear, consistent, and complete; all legal questions have a single correct answer; and judges are (in Blackstone's phrase) “living oracles” who deduce inexorable legal conclusions from indisputable legal axioms.<ref>Robert Samuel Summers, ''Instrumentalism and American Legal Theory''. Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1982, pp. 138-59.</ref>
Formalism was not Cardozo’s only target in ''The Nature of the Judicial Process''. He also attacked radical critics of formalism, such as John Chipman Gray, who claimed that judges have immense freedom and rejected the very idea of law as a set of binding rules. Gray and other proto-realists of the time tried to demystify law and view it with hard-headed pragmatism. They argued that since judges are the ultimate arbiters of law, “law” in the final analysis is whatever judges say it is (or what they predictably will say it is in the future). Cardozo argued that this isn’t an “analysis” of law, but a denial that any true law exists. The proto-realists confuse right with power. Judges may have the power to ignore settle legal standards, but they do not have the right. Moreover, the attempt to identify law with judicial rulings ignores the fact that the great majority of legal questions have clear, uncontroversial answers that guide everyday conduct and are never litigated in courts.<ref>Cardozo, ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'', pp. 126-30.</ref>
==Reception and influence==
''The Nature of the Judicial Process'' established Cardozo “as one of the leading jurists of his time”<ref>G. Edward White, ''The American Judicial tradition: Profiles of Leading American Judges.'' Expanded ed. New York: Oxford University Press, 1988, p. 258.</ref> and “has become a classic of legal education."<ref>White, ''The American Judicial Tradition'', p. 259.</ref> Its continuing appeal is due, in part, to its self-effacing tone, its lapidary prose, and its attempt to strike a happy medium between legal formalism and radical realist theories that wholly reject traditional views of law, legal reasoning, judicial restraint, and the rule of law.
The great success of Cardozo’s ''The Nature of the Judicial Process'' created demand for further reflections on the law.<ref>White, ''The American Judicial Tradition'', p. 259.</ref> In two later works, ''The Growth of Law'' (1924) and ''The Paradoxes of Legal Science'' (1927), Cardozo refined, deepened, and to some extent modified the views of law laid out in ''The Nature of the Judicial Process''.
==Notable quotations==
* The great generalities of the constitution have a content and a significance that vary from age to age. (17)
* Nothing is stable. Nothing absolute. All is fluid and changeable. There is an endless “becoming.” We are back with Heraclitus. (28)
* The final cause of law is the welfare of society. (66)
* A constitution states or ought to state not rules for the passing hour, but principles for an expanding future. (83)
* The great ideals of liberty and equality are preserved against the assaults of opportunism, the expediency of the passing hour, the erosion of small encroachments, the scorn and derision of those who have no patience with general principles, by enshrining them in constitutions, and consecrating to the task of their protection a body of defenders. (92)
* The judge, even when he is free, is still not wholly free. He is not to innovate at pleasure. He is not a knight-errant, roaming at will in pursuit of his own ideal of beauty or of goodness. He is to draw his inspiration from consecrated principles. (141)
* We shall have to feel our way here as elsewhere in the law. Somewhere between worship of the past and exaltation of the present, the path of safety will be found. (160)
* I was much troubled in spirit, in my first years upon the bench, to find how trackless was the ocean on which I had embarked. I sought for certainty. I was oppressed and disheartened when I found that the quest for it was futile. I was trying to reach land, the solid land of fixed and settled rules, the paradise of a justice that would declare itself by tokens plainer and more commanding than its pale and glimmering reflections in my own vacillating mind and conscience. (166)
* The great tides and currents which engulf the rest of men do not turn aside in their course and pass the judges by. (168)
* The future . . . is yours. We have been called to do our parts in an ageless process. Long after I am dead and gone, and my little part in it is forgotten, you will be here to do your share, and to carry the torch forward. I know that the flame will burn bright while the torch is in your keeping. (179-80)

{{About|protests and political opposition|the article about female toplessness in general (including in countries where it is both legal and accepted)|Toplessness}} {{globalise/West|date=December 2014}} [[File:Right to go topless cropped.jpg|thumb|right|A group of women protesting for the right to go topless anywhere a man could. Venice Beach, California, 2011 (demonstrator is wearing a [[pasties|pasty]])]]
'''Topfreedom''' is a [[cultural movement|cultural]] and [[political movement]] seeking changes in laws to allow women to be [[toplessness|topless]] in public places where men are permitted to be [[barechested]], as a form of [[gender equality]]. Specifically, the movement seeks the repeal or overturning of laws which restrict a woman's right not to have her chest covered at all times in public.
In addition, topfreedom advocates seek allowing nursing mothers to openly [[breastfeeding in public|breastfeed in public]], and women to [[bathe]] topless.
==Social and legal attitudes== {{See also|Indecent exposure|Public indecency}}
Many societies{{which|date=September 2015}} consider women who expose their nipples and areolae as [[modesty|immodest]] and contrary to [[social norms]]. In many jurisdictions{{which|date=September 2015}} a topless woman may be socially or officially harassed or cited for [[Lascivious|public lewdness]], [[indecent exposure]], [[public indecency]] or [[disorderly conduct]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feministezine.com/feminist/toplessness004.html|title=Topfreedom: The Fundamental Right of Women|author=Suzanne MacNevin|date=|website=The Feminist eZine|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref> Topfreedom advocates seek to change community attitudes to breasts as sex objects or indecent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.007b.com/topfreedom.php |title=What is Topfreedom? |publisher=007b.com |date=20 January 2013 |accessdate=12 August 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120232359/http://www.007b.com/topfreedom.php |archive-date=20 January 2013|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
Several countries in [[Europe]] have decriminalised non-sexual toplessness. Topless swimming and sunbathing on beaches has become acceptable in many parts of Europe, though the practice remains controversial in many places, and not common in most places. Many public swimming pools in Europe are owned by municipalities, which are treated as private organisations and allowed to set their [[dress code]]s.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
===Breastfeeding=== {{main|Breastfeeding in public}} In many countries around the world, [[breastfeeding in public]] is not unusual. During 2006–2010 and earlier, a number of news reports in the United States cited incidents where women were refused service or harassed for breastfeeding in public. In response, a majority of U.S. states have passed laws explicitly permitting nursing in public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncsl.org/IssuesResearch/Health/BreastfeedingLaws/tabid/14389/Default.aspx |title=Breastfeeding Laws |author= |date=March 2010 |website=Breastfeeding State Laws |publisher=NCSL |accessdate=14 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,200615,00.html |publisher=FOXNews.com |title=Indecent Exposure|first=Lis|last=Wiehl | date=2006-06-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.llli.org/llleaderweb/lv/lvjunjul05p51.html|title=Breastfeeding Legislation in the United States: A General Overview and Implications for Helping Mothers|author=|date=|website=|publisher=La Leche League International|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070331220518/http://www.llli.org/llleaderweb/LV/LVJunJul05p51.html|archivedate=2007-03-31|df=}}</ref> The United States federal government enacted a law in 1999<ref>{{cite web|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=106_cong_public_laws&docid=f:publ058.106 |title=Treasury and General Government Appropriations Act, 2000|accessdate=2010-01-14}}</ref> which specifically provides that "a woman may breastfeed her child at any location in a Federal building or on Federal property, if the woman and her child are otherwise authorized to be present at the location." However, these laws generally do not apply to rules imposed by private organizations or on private property, such as restaurants, airlines, or shopping malls.
== Asia ==
=== Taiwan ===
In support of [[Adda Smaradottir]]'s FreeTheNipple act in public cyberspace,<ref name="LUS">{{cite web | url=https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100001875440525&sk=photos&collection_token=100001875440525%3A2305272732%3A69&set=a.848235281915645&type=1&pnref=story | title=裸 for FreeTheNipple | publisher=林郁璇 | year=2015 | accessdate=April 25, 2015 | language=Chinese | quote=[https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100001875440525&sk=photos&collection_token=100001875440525%3A2305272732%3A69&set=a.848235281915645&type=1&pnref=story 裸 for FreeTheNipple]}}</ref> young women uploaded their topless photos to [[Facebook]] and protested against its Community Standards<ref name="fbcs">{{cite web | url=https://www.facebook.com/communitystandards/ | title=Community Standards | publisher=[[Facebook]] | year=2015 | accessdate=April 25, 2015 | quote=[https://www.facebook.com/communitystandards/ Community Standards]}}</ref> of considering women's breasts as sexual materials. Those photos and related news articles were blocked initially,<ref name="appledaily">{{cite web | url=http://www.appledaily.com.tw/appledaily/article/headline/20150412/36489627/ | title=太陽花５女將露乳 fb讓步po照 | publisher=蘋果日報 | year=2015 | accessdate=April 25, 2015 | language=Chinese | quote=[http://www.appledaily.com.tw/appledaily/article/headline/20150412/36489627/ 太陽花５女將露乳 fb讓步po照]}}</ref> but [[Facebook]] considered those photos did not violate Community Standards.<ref name="LUS"/>
== Europe ==
=== Denmark === Bathing and sunbathing in the nude (including topless) is legal on Danish beaches.<ref name=DKNu>Strandguiden: [http://www.strandguiden.dk/index.php?id=609 Lovgivningen om nøgenbadning.] Retrieved 8 July 2016.</ref> Nudity and toplessness in other public outdoor places is generally also legal, unless it is involves "offensive conduct" or is likely to cause public outrage.<ref name=DKNu/><ref>[[Nordjyske Stiftstidende]] (2 August 2013). [http://nordjyske.dk/nyheder/noegen-i-det-groenne/8e6b337a-f972-4b21-b4a2-23f548b33ed6/112/1513 Nøgen i det grønne.] Retrieved 8 June 2016.</ref> The public outrage law is rarely used in practice, but in 1972 audience members were convicted of being nude in the [[Royal Danish Theatre]].<ref name=DKNu/> In December 2007, a group of women and men calling themselves Topless Front swam topless in public swim baths to promote topless equality.<ref name=polalti>{{cite news |url=http://politiken.dk/indland/article506929.ece |publisher=[[Politiken]] |date=19 December 2009 |title=Topløs svømning har altid været tilladt}}</ref> In March 2008, after a campaign by the group, [[Copenhagen]]'s Culture and Leisure Committee voted to allow topless bathing in its swimming pools.<ref name="Victory for topless bathers">{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/article977650.ece |title= Victory for topless bathers |publisher=TheSun.com |date= 2008-03-29|accessdate=2010-06-14 |location=London}}</ref> After the Committee had voted, it was revealed that no laws had existed against topless bathing, effectively making the vote unnecessary. However, some public baths had (and have) restricted it themselves.<ref name=polalti/> Public breastfeeding is supported by the vast majority of both sexes in Denmark,<ref>BT (7 April 2007). [http://www.b.dk/danmark/cafe-amning-er-ok Café-amning er ok]. Retrieved 8 June 2016.</ref> is entirely legal and accepted almost all places, except for a few private cafés and restaurants that have restricted it.<ref>Amme Net: [http://www.ammenet.dk/wiki/offentlig-amning Offentlig amning]. Retrieved 8 June 2016.</ref><ref>[[Politiken]] (28 September 2011). [http://politiken.dk/mad/madnyt/ECE1406478/guide-her-er-du-fri-for-bare-bryster-midt-i-maden/ Guide: Her er du fri for bare bryster midt i maden.] Retrieved 8 June 2016.</ref><ref>BT (27 September 2011). [http://www.bt.dk/danmark/loven-stoetter-ammeforbud-paa-cafeer Loven støtter ammeforbud på cafeer.] Retrieved 8 June 2016.</ref>
=== France === In France, the feminist collective [[Les TumulTueuses]] organized a topfree protest in Paris in May 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/societe/20090507.OBS6010/des-feministes-enlevent-le-haut-dans-une-piscine-a-paris.html|title=Des féministes enlèvent le haut dans une piscine à Paris|trans-title=Feminists Remove their Tops in Paris Pool|author=|date=7 May 2009|publisher=Le Nouvel Observateur|language=fr}}</ref>
=== Greece === In [[Greece]] toplessness is not illegal and is widely practiced by locals and tourists alike as there are no cultural taboos against it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eirinika.gr/article/35252/aytes-einai-17-paralies-stin-ellada-opoy-mporeite-na-kanete-mpaniogymnoi-tha-tolmisete|title=Αυτές είναι 17 παραλίες στην Ελλάδα όπου μπορείτε να κάνετε μπάνιο...γυμνοί-Θα το τολμήσετε;|trans-title=These are 17 Beaches in Greece where you can Swim ... Naked - Will you Dare?|language=greek|author=|date=2 July 2014|website=eirinika.gr|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetoc.gr/magazine/oi-10-wraioteres-paralies-gia-gumnismo-stin-ellada|title=Οι 10 ωραιότερες παραλίες για γυμνισμό στην Ελλάδα |trans-title=The 10 Best Beaches for Nudism in Greece|language=Greek|author=|accessdate=21 July 2017|website=The Toc}}</ref>
=== Poland === In [[Poland]] in 2008–2009, two women from [[Szczecin]] including [[glamour model]] [[Dorota Krzysztofek]],<ref name="ckm">{{cite web | url=http://www.ckm.pl/szukaj,Dorota%20Krzysztofek,2,3,0,1,1,sa.html | title=Dorota Krzysztofek | publisher=[[CKM (adult magazine)|CKM]] | website=Galerie | year=2012 | accessdate=July 22, 2012 | language=Polish | quote=[http://www.ckm.pl/dziewczyny/dorota-krzysztofek,80,img,1,gna.html CKM photo session.]}}</ref> won a court battle that reasserted the women's right to sunbathe topless on public beaches.<ref name="pardon">{{cite web | url=http://www.pardon.pl/artykul/7705/sad_w_polsce_wolno_chodzic_topless | title=Sąd: w Polsce wolno chodzić topless! (Court: you can go topless in Poland) | publisher=Pardon | website=Polityka, Prawdy, Emocje | date=February 4, 2009 | accessdate=July 22, 2012 | author=Magda Hartman | language=Polish}}</ref> Krzysztofek, along with her female companion, were fined by local municipal officials for topless sunbathing at a public recreation area. The women refused to pay the fine and took the matter to [[Civil Court]]. Their first hearing had to be postponed due to remarkable media interest.<ref name="wyborcza">{{cite web | url=http://wyborcza.pl/1,75248,5558277,W_obronie_topless_pojdzie_nawet_do_Strasburga.html | title=W obronie topless pójdzie nawet do Strasburga | publisher=[[Gazeta Wyborcza]], [[Szczecin]] | website=Artykuły | date=August 6, 2008 | accessdate=July 22, 2012 | author=Andrzej Kulej | language=Polish}}</ref>
On November 7, 2008, judge Szczepańska upheld the city staff decision, and charged the women with indecent exposure, explaining that their personal freedoms cannot encroach on the freedoms of families with children who frequent the same recreation spot. Although topless sunbathing is not prohibited in Poland, the judge sentenced them to pay a fine of 230 [[zloty]] (150 zloty by different source,<ref name="france24">{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20081107-polish-court-reprimands-topless-sunbathers |title=Polish court reprimands topless sunbathers |publisher=France 24 (after AFP News Briefs) |date=January 10, 2009|accessdate=July 22, 2012 |author=AFP |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090110125209/http://www.france24.com/en/20081107-polish-court-reprimands-topless-sunbathers |archivedate=January 10, 2009 }}</ref> or [[euro|€]]40, [[dollar|$]]55) for breaking the rules of conduct. In her rationale, the judge also said that it is not up to the defendants to teach youngsters human anatomy; however, her decision was appealed by Krzysztofek's female friend soon afterwards, with the plea of not guilty.<ref name="pardon"/><ref name="attuworld">{{cite web|url=http://attuworld.com/girls/polish-court-reprimands-topless-sunbathers.html |title=Polish court reprimands topless sunbathers |publisher=''Attuworld.com'' |accessdate=July 22, 2012 |author=Attu editorial |quote=[https://web.archive.org/web/20100102182403/http://attugirls.com/blonde/dorota-krzysztofek-from-poland.html Dorota Krzysztofek from Poland busted for topless sunbathing. CKM Gallery.] |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725100346/http://attuworld.com/girls/polish-court-reprimands-topless-sunbathers.html |archivedate=July 25, 2011 }}</ref>
The appellate court declared both women to be innocent,<ref name="wyborcza.pl-2">{{cite web | url=http://wyborcza.pl/1,76842,6232762,Topless_jest_legalny.html | title=Topless jest legalny | publisher=[[Gazeta Wyborcza]], Szczecin | date=April 2, 2009 | accessdate=July 22, 2012 | author=Adam Zadworny | language=Polish}}</ref> because the city staff were unable to prove that anyone at the beach was indignant or scandalized by their toplessness, and no complaint was ever reported. On the contrary, some visitors stood up to their defense. There were no signs at the recreation area against what is otherwise legal.<ref name="france24"/> The appellate court's decision was binding, but it also created an aura of ambivalence, with topless sunbathing in public declared acceptable only if nobody else including families with children formally objects to it.<ref name="pardon"/><ref name="polandian">{{cite web | url=http://polandian.wordpress.com/2009/02/05/topless-women-soften-polish-court/ | title=Topless women soften Polish court (entertainment, photo credit: Getty Images) | publisher=''Polandian''. Understanding Poland | date=February 5, 2009 | accessdate=July 22, 2012 | author=Jamie Stokes}}</ref>
=== Sweden === In Sweden, toplessness is not illegal. However, private or public establishments are permitted to establish [[dress code]]s which may require women to wear tops, and deny access or remove individuals who breach these standards. In September 2007, "[[Bara Bröst]]" (a pun meaning both "Just Breasts" and "Bare Breasts") appeared to promote topless equality in these semi-public facilities. The group staged several events in public swim baths in September and October 2007, starting in [[Uppsala]] from which they were evicted several times, before succeeding in [[Sundsvall]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/weird/76183-swedes-fight-for-topless-rights |publisher=Metro.co.uk|date=November 19, 2007|title=Swedes fight for topless rights}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thelocal.se/9599/20080108/ Victory for topless bathers] Article from The Local</ref>
The group scored a victory in June 2009 when the [[Malmö]] city's sports and recreation committee approved new rules that, while requiring everybody to wear bathing suits at indoor public swimming pools, did not require women to cover their breasts.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thelocal.se/20250/20090624/ |publisher=[[The Local]] |date=24 June 2009 |title=Malmö win for topless Swedish bathers}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/27519/swedish-city-legalizes-topless-bathingat-public-swimming-pools/ |title=Swedish city legalizes topless bathing at public swimming pools |publisher=Inquisitr.com |date=2009-06-27 |accessdate=2009-07-23}}</ref> "We don't define what bathing suits men should wear so it doesn't make much sense to do it for women. And besides, it's not unusual for men to have large breasts that resemble women's breasts", said a council spokesman.<ref name="Inquisitr.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/27519/swedish-city-legalizes-topless-bathingat-public-swimming-pools/ |title=Swedish city legalizes topless bathing....at public swimming pools |publisher=Inquisitr.com |date=2009-06-27 |accessdate=2009-07-23}}</ref>
== North America == === Canada === {{main|Topfreedom in Canada}} [[File:Vancouver Pride 2009 (31).jpg|thumb|Topless women at [[Vancouver Pride Festival]]]]
In 1991 toplessness as an indecent act was challenged by Gwen Jacob in [[Guelph]], [[Ontario]], who removed her shirt and was charged with indecency. Part of her defence was the [[double standard]]s between men and women. Although she was convicted, this was overturned by the Court of Appeal.<ref name="QueenvsJacob">{{Cite journal| url = http://www.canlii.org/en/on/onca/doc/1996/1996canlii1119/1996canlii1119.html | title = Judgment C12668, R. vs. Jacob | date = 1996-12-09 | publisher = Province of Ontario Court of Appeal | accessdate = 2009-02-16| postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> This case determined that being topless is not indecent under the meaning of the Criminal Code. However it did not establish any constitutional right of equality. This case subsequently led to the acquittal of women in [[British Columbia]] and [[Saskatchewan]] who faced similar charges. Although each province and territory technically reserves its right to interpret the law as it pleases, the Ontario case has proven influential. Since the matter has not been determined by the [[Supreme Court of Canada]], it is still possible that a woman could be convicted elsewhere in Canada, but interpretation of moral law in Canada has become increasingly liberalized.<ref>Valverde, Mariana (1999). [http://myweb.dal.ca/mgoodyea/Documents/Law/The%20harms%20of%20sex%20and%20the%20risks%20of%20of%20breasts%20Valverde%20Social%20Leg%20Stud%201999%208%282%29%20181-197.pdf "The Harms of Sex and the Risks of Breasts: Obscenity and Indecency in Canadian Law"]. ''Social Legal Studies'' (8): 181.</ref> There do not appear to have been any further women charged in Canada since these cases were determined.
=== United States === In the United States, states have primary jurisdiction in matters of public morality. The topfreedom movement has claimed success in a few instances in persuading some state and federal courts to overturn some state laws on the basis of [[sex discrimination]] or [[equal protection]], arguing that a woman should be free to expose her chest in any context in which a man can expose his. Other successful cases have been on the basis of freedom of expression in protest, or simply that exposure of breasts is not indecent (or similar terminology).
Laws and ordinances barring female toplessness are being challenged in federal courts around the nation. Each lawsuit, if it prevails at the appellate level, will legalize topfreedom in the following U.S. circuits of appeal (from west to east): 9 (California), 10 (Colorado), 8 (Missouri) and 4 (Maryland). A federal lawsuit in the 7th Circuit (Illinois), was lost at the appellate level and the petition for review by the U.S. Supreme Court was denied.

==== Colorado ==== On February 22, 2017, U.S. District Judge R. Brooke Jackson granted a [[preliminary injunction]] against a Fort Collins ordinance banning female toplessness saying it likely violates the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] due to gender-based discrimination. Britt Hoagland, Samantha Six and Free the Nipple - Fort Collins brought the case in May 2016. The judge wrote: ''the naked female breast is seen as disorderly or dangerous because society, from Renaissance paintings to Victoria's Secret commercials, has conflated female breasts with genitalia and stereotyped them as such. The irony is that by forcing women to cover up their bodies, society has made naked women's breasts something to see.'' <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4252844/Judge-blocks-Colorado-college-town-s-ban-topless-women.html |title=Judge in Colorado blocks town's ban on topless women calling it unconstitutional |date= February 23, 2017 |publisher= Daily Mail.com |accessdate=2017-02-25}}</ref> Fort Collins is appealing the district court's ruling to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=http://www.westword.com/news/free-the-nipple-topless-order-being-fought-by-fort-collins-8903249 |title=Fighting Free the Nipple Topless Order Will Cost Fort Collins $250K, Attorney Says |date= March 23, 2017 |publisher= Westword.com |accessdate=2017-03-23}}</ref> On January 17, 2018, a three-judge panel of the 10th Circuit heard Fort Collins' appeal of the preliminary injunction ruling.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.delmarvanow.com/story/news/2018/01/17/free-nipple-apppeal/1040824001// |title=Appeals court hears Fort Collins topless ban arguments |date= January 17, 2018 |publisher= USA Today Network |accessdate=2018-07-29}}</ref> If the district court's ruling is upheld on appeal, discriminatory anti-topless laws in the territory of the Tenth Circuit (Wyoming, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Kansas, and Oklahoma) will be unenforceable.
[[Denver]] and [[Boulder, Colorado|Boulder]] do not distinguish between male and female toplessness.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/politics/news/a48090/fort-collins-topless-law-colorado/ |title=Women Won't Be Able to Go Topless in Fort Collins After All |date= October 22, 2015 |publisher= Cosmopolitan |accessdate=2017-02-25}}</ref>
==== Florida ==== A Florida statute about indecent exposure prohibits the vulgar or indecent exposure of sexual organs but does not specify if female breasts are included as sexual organs. The right to breastfeed in public is expressly protected,<ref>{{cite web|publisher=The Florida Legislature|title=Lewdness; Indecent Exposure – Sec. 800.03 Fla. Stat|year=2014|url=http://www.leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0800-0899/0800/Sections/0800.03.html|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> and one Florida court inferred that this exception indicates that female breasts are sexual organs<ref>Kitts v. State, 766 So. 2d 1067 (Fla. 5th DCA 1999)</ref> and the Supreme Court of Florida held that a separate statute about disorderly conduct can be used to prosecute female toplessness.<ref>Moffett v. State, 340 So. 2d 1155 (Fla. 1976).</ref> Courts have rejected equal protection arguments.
The right of a woman to ''protest'' topless has been held to be a freedom of expression and not an equal protection issue.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} For example, in 2007, a Florida court acquitted a woman of indecent exposure for being topless on [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]] because of the political nature of her stand, under the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] right of free speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gotopless.org/news.php?item.8.1|title=On Sept 25, 2007, Daytona Beach, FL loses topless case|first=|last=|date=25 September 2007 |website=GoTopless}}</ref> Although there is only one known public place throughout the state where female toplessness is officially allowed (a [[nude beach]] located at [[Haulover Park]], in [[Bal Harbour]]), topless bathing is tolerated on [[South Beach]], along with a number of hotel pools in [[Miami Beach]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Muench-Pace|first=Dawn|title=Topless and Nude Beaches in Miami|url=http://gomiami.about.com/od/naturebeachesparks/a/ToplessBeaches.htm|publisher=About.com|accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=O'Neill|first=Natalie|title=Topless Protesters on South Beach|url=http://www.miaminewtimes.com/2008-09-04/news/topless-protesters-on-south-beach/|accessdate=24 August 2017|newspaper=Miami New Times|date=September 4, 2008}}</ref>
====Illinois==== Sonoko Tagami, a [[GoTopless]] activist, was ticketed for toplessness and fined $100 plus $40 in fees.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-topless-lawsuit-met-20141112-story.html |title=Woman sues Chicago over right to bare breasts in public |date= November 13, 2014 |publisher= Chicago Tribune |accessdate=2017-04-01}}</ref> Tagami filed a federal lawsuit challenging the ordinance but the trial judge dismissed the case without a trial. She then appealed the dismissal to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit]]. The appeal was heard by a three-judge panel on November 1, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wbez.org/shows/wbez-news/will-topless-protester-get-her-day-in-court/fcb598d9-37ae-47fc-8b87-2477145dfa1f |title=Will Topless Protester Get Her Day In Court? |date= November 1, 2016 |publisher= WBEZ91.5CHICAGO |accessdate=2017-04-01}}</ref> On November 8, 2017, a divided three-judge panel upheld Illinois' ban on female topfreedom two to one.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chicagoinc/ct-met-topless-law-1112-chicago-inc-20171110-story.html |title=Chicago's ban on uncovered women's breasts upheld by divided court |date= November 10, 2017 |publisher= Chicago Tribune |accessdate=2017-11-27}}</ref> On March 12, 2018, Tagami petitioned to appeal her loss before the [[United States Supreme Court]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/gotopless-activist-files-petition-to-the-us-supreme-court-300616001.html |title=GoTopless activist files petition to the U.S. Supreme Court |date= March 20, 2018 |publisher= PRNewswire |accessdate=2018-04-16}}</ref> On April 16, 2018, her petition was denied.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/search.aspx?filename=/docket/docketfiles/html/public/17-1293.html |title=Docket No. 17-1293 |publisher= United States Supreme Court |accessdate=2018-04-16}}</ref>

====Maryland==== On May 20, 2017, Captain Butch Arbin, head of the [[Ocean City, Maryland|Ocean City]] Beach Patrol instructed workers to document complaints of toplessness, but not approach topless women, even if the complainants requested it. Arbin changed the beach patrol's policy since the [[Maryland Attorney General]] has not released an opinion about female public toplessness in response to a formal request last year by a female resident and a topfree advocate who uses the pseudonym "Chelsea Covington."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4585730/Maryland-Beach-patrol-says-women-allowed-topless.html |title=Women will NOT be fined for going toplesss says Captain of Maryland Beach Patrol |date= June 8, 2017 |publisher= DailyMail.com |accessdate=2017-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://breastsarehealthy.wordpress.com/2017/06/09/ocean-city-maryland-and-topfreedom/ |title=Ocean City, Maryland and Topfreedom |date= June 9, 2017 |accessdate=2017-09-07}}</ref> In response, on June 10, 2017, the town held an emergency meeting and passed Emergency Ordinance 2017-10, which made it unlawful for all females of all ages to be bare-chested in public, for purposes other than breastfeeding, in the same locations where it is lawful for males to be bare-chested. Violations of the ordinance will result in a $1,000, fine. On January 16, 2018, Chelsea C. Eline, and four other women, represented by national civil rights attorney, Devon M. Jacob, of Jacob Litigation, filed a federal lawsuit against Ocean City.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/fight-over-ocean-citys-ban-on-bare-breasts-goes-to-federal-court/2018/01/18/349ed060-fc6b-11e7-8f66-2df0b94bb98a_story.html/ |title=Fight over Ocean City's ban on bare breasts goes to federal court |date= January 18, 2018 |publisher= The Washington Post |accessdate=2018-01-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.JacobLitigation.com|title=Jacob Litigation {{!}} A Civil Rights Law Firm|website=www.jacoblitigation.com|access-date=2018-10-06}}</ref> The lawsuit is captioned <u>Eline, et al. v. Town of Ocean City, MD, et al.</u>, No. JKB-18-0145 (D.MD). The lawsuit seeks preliminary and permanent injunctive relief. On June 29, 2018, the Plaintiffs filed a motion for a [[preliminary injunction]]. On July 27, 2018, the Defendant filed a Memorandum in Opposition. On August 9, 2018, Plaintiffs filed a Reply Brief. On August 22, 2018, the Court issued an Order, setting a hearing on the motion for September 21, 2018. On September 19, 2018, the Court issued an Order granting Plaintiffs’ motion to reschedule the hearing for the purpose of providing time for expert discovery to be completed prior to the hearing. In the Order, the Court set expert discovery deadlines: Plaintiffs, on or before October 5, 2018, and Defendant, on or before November 5, 2018. The Court rescheduled the hearing to December 7, 2018, at 11:00 AM. On October 5, 2018, Plaintiffs filed an expert report from Debby Herbenick, PhD, MPH, CSE.
==== Massachusetts ==== In December 2007, 50 residents of [[Pittsfield, Massachusetts]] petitioned the City Council requesting a segregated beach for topless sunbathing by both men and women. The petition was rejected by the council, with the Mayor calling it "unacceptable and unnecessary". Proponents of topless sunbathing vowed to continue their fight.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jonathanmelleonpolitics.blogspot.com/2007/11/pittsfields-revitalization-via-perverse.html |title=I Publius Ripped from the Headlines Once Again |date=December 8, 2007 |publisher=Berkshire Eagle |accessdate=2009-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://tera.ca/#September25 |title=Topfree Equal Rights Association - Recent News |date=December 8, 2007 |publisher=TERA |accessdate=2009-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.topix.com/forum/city/pittsfield-ma/TTN12JKL1OKEM4OC8 |title=Pittsfield petition calls for topless sunbathing |date=December 7, 2007 |publisher=Topix.com |accessdate=2009-02-06}}</ref> In 2010, 200 residents of Pittsfield placed a question on the ballot asking whether State laws should be clarified to allow topless sunbathing equally for both men and women.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-25502650.html |title=Topless Sunbathing Plan on Ballot in Pittsfield |date= August 15, 2010 |publisher=The Boston Globe |accessdate=2010-08-15}}</ref> The proposal was defeated 2,934 to 6,855.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pittsfield votes no on nudity|url=http://www.berkshireeagle.com/ci_16506630|publisher=Berkshire Eagle|author=David Pepose|date=November 3, 2010}}</ref>
==== Missouri ==== On October 26, 2015, the [[ACLU]] of Missouri, on behalf of Jessica Lawson and Amber Hutchison representing "Free the Nipple—Springfield Residents Promoting Equality," filed suit against the [[Springfield, Missouri|City of Springfield]] over its anti-topless ordinance in the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri|District Court for the Western District of Missouri]] of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit]]. On January 22, 2016, the court granted a preliminary injunction barring the enforcement of the ordinance.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.aclu-mo.org/legal-docket/free-the-nipple-v-city-of-springfield/ |title=Free the Nipple v. City of Springfield |publisher= American Civil Liberties Union of Missouri|accessdate=2017-03-23}}</ref> On October 5, 2017, a federal judge upheld Springfield's ordinance that requires a woman, but not a man, to completely cover their areola with an opaque material.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ky3.com/content/news/Federal-judge-rules-for-city-of-Springfield-in-Free-the-Nipple-lawsuit-449659103.html |title=Federal judge rules for city of Springfield in 'Free the Nipple' lawsuit |publisher= KY3|accessdate=2018-09-28}}</ref>
==== Nebraska ==== The [[Lincoln, Nebraska|City of Lincoln]] has an ordinance prohibiting women from being topless.<ref name="auto"/>
==== New Hampshire ==== In February 2016, a judge dismissed<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hVJGEtcO_aU|title=Free the Nipple Trial - Full Video|first=|last=FreeKeene|date=28 December 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> a case against two female "Free the Nipple" activists, Heidi Lilley and Barbara MacKinnon, who were cited for being topless at Gilford beach.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nh1.com/news/update-free-the-nipple-organizer-cited-for-toplessness-in-gilford/|title=UPDATE: Free the Nipple organizer cited for toplessness in Gilford|first=Tyler|last=Dumont|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20150823/NEWHAMPSHIRE02/150829721|title=Women go topless to send message of equality at Hampton Beach - New Hampshire|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20150907/NEWHAMPSHIRE02/150909366|title='Free-the-Nipple' movement draws anger, tickets in Gilford - New Hampshire|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20150909/NEWS03/150909224|title=Police say topless women violated beach ordinance - New Hampshire|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionleader.com/NH-topless-movement-leader-goes-to-trial-in-December|title=N.H. topless movement leader goes to trial in December - New Hampshire|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionleader.com/Toplessness-charge-lands-woman-in-court-today|title=Toplessness charge lands woman in court today - New Hampshire|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="auto1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2016/02/02/n-h-judge-dismisses-case-against-women-ticketed-for-going-topless-at-beach/|title=N.H. judge dismisses case against women ticketed for going topless at beach|date=2 February 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unionleader.com/Judge-dismisses-charge-against-one-of-several-women-arrested-for-going-topless-on-Gilford-beach|title=Judge dismisses charge against one of several women arrested for going topless on Gilford beach - New Hampshire|publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://www.concordmonitor.com/laconia-judge-orders-against-free-the-nipple-topless-protesters-6291035</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laconiadailysun.com/newsx/local-news/95171-mayor-declines-to-recommend-lilley-for-city-council-agenda|title=Mayor says 'no' to putting Free the Nipple on city agenda|publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://www.concordmonitor.com/Gilford-NH-Laconia-NH-Free-the-Nipple-movement-Ray-Duckler-2568051</ref> Because the judge decided "the town lacked authority for a prosecution because there is no state law that prohibits the exposure of female breasts in public," and the town "lacked authority for a criminal prosecution that's neither prohibited by the criminal code nor by statute," a bill to ban women from exposing their nipples in public was introduced. The bill would make it a misdemeanor for women to show their breasts or nipples in public with "reckless disregard" for whether it would offend someone. The New Hampshire chapter of the ACLU opposed the bill.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_29577772/new-hampshire-lawmakers-push-ban-topless-women-warning |title=New Hampshire lawmakers push ban on topless women, warning of nudity at libraries, Little League games |publisher=San Jose Mercury News |accessdate=2016-03-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nhpr.org/post/judge-dismisses-case-against-women-who-went-topless-beach |title=Judge Dismisses Case Against Women Who Went Topless at Beach |date= February 3, 2016 |publisher=New Hampshire Public Radio |accessdate=2016-03-09}}</ref> On March 9, 2016, the proposed ban legislation was defeated.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.courant.com/politics/hc-ap-nipple-bill-new-hampshire-20160309-story.html |title=New Hampshire Won't Ban Women From Showing Breasts, Nipples |date= March 9, 2016 |publisher=Hartford Courant |accessdate=2016-03-09}}</ref> On February 1, 2018, the appeal was heard by the state supreme court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5340997/New-Hampshires-highest-court-hears-topless-beachgoers-case.html|title=City law banning beachgoers going topless is 'unconstitutional and discriminatory' says lawyer for three women arrested for refusing to put their tops on when other bathers complained|publisher=DailyMail|accessdate=2018-02-01}}</ref>
==== New Jersey ==== In 2008, Jill Coccaro, aka Phoenix Feeley,<ref name=durante/> of New York City (see also [[Topfreedom#New York|New York]], below) visited the beach at [[Spring Lake, New Jersey]]. She did not wear a top and was arrested when she refused to cover up. She was given a T-shirt but left the police department and took it off, and was arrested again.<ref name=durante/> She was charged with violating a borough ordinance prohibiting public nudity. She appealed the conviction to the state appeals court, and the two-judge panel—one man, one woman—ruled against her.<ref name=durante>{{cite news|last=Durante|first=Thomas|title=Breasts are a moral 'threat': Court rules topless sunbathing violates 'public sensibilities' |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2037604/Breasts-moral-threat-New-Jersey-rules-topless-sunbather-Phoenix-Feeley-bizarre-ruling.html|accessdate=12 February 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail UK|date=September 15, 2011}}</ref> "Restrictions on the exposure of the female breast are supported by the important governmental interest in safeguarding the public's moral sensibilities." The court cited ''State of New Jersey v. Arlene Vogt'' (2001) as precedent.<ref name=baxter>{{cite web|last=Baxter|first=Christopher|title=State appeals court rejects N.Y. woman's fight to go topless in public|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2011/09/state_appeals_court_rejects_ny.html|publisher=New Jersey On-Line LLC|accessdate=12 February 2012|date=September 15, 2011}}</ref> In that case, Vogt was fined after she appeared on Higbee Beach in [[Cape May County, New Jersey]] without a shirt.<ref>{{cite web|title=NJ v Arlene Vogt|url=http://naturisteducation.org/Toni_Egbert_Library/State_Appellate_Courts/NJ_v_Arlene_Vogt/nj_v_arlene_vogt.html|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>
In the five years since she was found guilty and fined, she appealed the case to the New Jersey state appellate court, who ruled against her. The [[New Jersey Supreme Court]] refused to hear her appeal.<ref name=bodner>{{cite news|last=Bodner|first=Brett|title=Brett|url=http://www.dailyrecord.com/article/20130806/NJNEWS10/308060043/Woman-who-went-topless-Spring-Lake-2008-now-jail-after-refusing-pay-fines|accessdate=25 August 2013|newspaper=Daily record|date=Aug 6, 2013}}</ref> Legally representing herself, she then appealed to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]], but it too refused to hear her appeal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phoenix Feeley v NJ|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/Search.aspx?FileName=/docketfiles/13-5801.htm|accessdate=June 15, 2014}}</ref>
She would not pay the $816 fine, telling Judge George Pappas, "I refuse to pay the fines for an act that is legal for a man, but not legal for a woman." The judge sentenced her to 16 days but she was released after only eight for good behavior. Ron Taft, a Manhattan attorney, offered to pay her fine but Coccaro refused, desiring to make a point. She went on a hunger strike. The GoTopless group organized a protest outside the jail where Coccaro was held,<ref name=bodner/> but only two individuals attended. Taft commented, "The point is, there are guys with larger breasts than women, and sometimes they take their top off."<ref name=kemp>{{cite news|last=Kemp|first=Joe|title=BUST-ed! Topless advocate calls 16 days in New Jersey jail 'death sentence'|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/bust-ed-topless-advocate-calls-16-days-new-jersey-jail-death-sentence-article-1.1422205|accessdate=25 August 2013|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=August 9, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Racioppi|first=Dustin|title=Topless activist Phoenix Feeley free from jail; 'They couldn't break me'|url=http://www.app.com/article/20130815/NJNEWS14/308150058/Phoenix-Feeley-topless-jail|accessdate=25 August 2013|date=August 15, 2013}}</ref>
==== New Mexico ==== The [[City of Albuquerque]] has an anti-topless ordinance.<ref name="auto"/>
==== New York ==== In 1986, seven women who picnicked topless were charged in [[Rochester, New York]] with baring "that portion of the breast which is below the top of the areola".<ref>[[New York Penal Law|Penal Law]] § 245.01 has since been amended. For the [http://law.onecle.com/new-york/penal/PEN0245.01_245.01.html present version]: <br>A person is guilty of exposure if he appears in a public place in such a manner that the private or intimate parts of his body are unclothed or exposed. For purposes of this section, the private or intimate parts of a female person shall include that portion of the breast which is below the top of the areola. This section shall not apply to the breastfeeding of infants or to any person entertaining or performing in a play, exhibition, show or entertainment.</ref> That law had originally been enacted to discourage 'topless' waitresses. The women were initially convicted, but on appeal two of the women's charges were reversed by the New York State Court of Appeals in 1992 on equal protection grounds in ''Santorelli's'' case.<ref name=Santorelli>{{cite web|title=NY v Santorelli|url=http://naturisteducation.org/Toni_Egbert_Library/State_Supreme_Courts/NY_v_Santorelli/ny_v_santorelli.html|publisher=Naturist Education Foundation|accessdate=12 February 2012|date=July 7, 1992}}</ref><ref name=cornell>{{cite web|title=The People &C., Respondent, ''V''. Ramona Santorelli and Mary Lou Schloss|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/nyctap/I92_0160.htm|accessdate=13 March 2012|publisher=New York Court of Appeals |date= July 7, 1992}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Zuckerman|first=Esther|title=Yes, Ladies, You Can Walk Around the City Topless|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2011/06/topless_bowery.php|accessdate=8 February 2012|newspaper=Village Voice|date=June 9, 2011}}</ref><ref name=gotopless>{{cite web|url=http://www.gotopless.org/news.php?item.3.1|title=10 successful cases giving women the right to be topless in certain states or cities|publisher=GoTopless.org|accessdate=2009-09-28}}</ref>
Jill Coccaro, aka Phoenix Feeley,<ref name=durante/> of New York City, was arrested in 2005 in New York City for walking along a street without wearing a shirt. She sued the city for violating a New York State Supreme Court ruling in ''Santorelli's'' case which had declared that women can go topless in public.<ref name=Santorelli /> The city finally paid $29,000 to settle her lawsuit. The [[Outdoor Co-ed Topless Pulp Fiction Appreciation Society]] has since 2011 organized regular gatherings around New York City of women who read books in public while topless.<ref>{{cite web|title=Outdoor Co-ed Topless Pulp Fiction Appreciation Society|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/07/co-ed-topless-pulp-fiction-reading-naked_n_952510.html|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=8 February 2012|date=Sep 7, 2011}}</ref> The objective of the group, besides enjoying the sun and book reading, is to create awareness that New York law allows toplessness in public and to change social attitudes to the exposure of breasts. Although participation has been very small, there has been no harassment of the participants either by the police or the public. The Topless New York series, created by an anonymous New York City photographer in 2007, is another effort to raise awareness of women's topless rights in New York State, and normalize the exercise of those rights, by publishing photographs of women topless in public all over New York City and other areas of New York State.<ref>{{cite web|title=Topless New York|url=https://twitter.com/ToplessNewYork|publisher=Topless New York|accessdate=14 November 2016|date=2007–2016}}</ref>
[[Holly Van Voast]], a Bronx photographer and performance artist, was detained, arrested or issued summonses 10 times during 2011 and 2012. Among other places, she went topless on the [[Staten Island Ferry]],<ref name=flegenheimer/> at the Oyster Bar in [[Grand Central Terminal]], in front of an elementary school, on a train, and outside a [[Hooters|Hooters restaurant]].<ref name=goodman/> After her arrest in front of the Hooters, police officers took her to a hospital for a psychiatric evaluation. On October 11, 2011, she appeared in the Midtown Community Court and promptly removed her top, baring her breasts, in front of the judge.<ref name=flegenheimer>{{cite news|last=Flegenheimer|first=Matt|title=In Court for Disrobing, and Doing It Again|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/13/nyregion/answering-a-summons-on-disrobing-and-disrobing-in-court.html|accessdate=25 August 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=October 12, 2011}}</ref> All the charges were dismissed. Van Voast filed a federal lawsuit on May 15 against the city and the police department.<ref name=goodman>{{cite news|last=Goodman|first=J. David|title=See Topless Woman? Just Move On, Police Are Told|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/16/nyregion/a-police-roll-call-reminder-women-may-go-topless.html|accessdate=25 August 2013|date=May 15, 2013}}</ref>
In February 2013, the New York City Police Department issued a command to all its officers through their daily roll call. It reminded officers that they are not to cite or arrest a woman for public lewdness, indecent exposure or any other section of the [[New York Penal Law|Penal Law]] for "simply exposing their breasts in public."<ref name=goodman/>
====Oregon==== Oregon's indecent exposure law criminalizes only nudity that is intended to sexually arouse the public. The cities of [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Eugene, Oregon|Eugene]], [[Ashland, Oregon|Ashland]] and [[Happy Valley, Oregon|Happy Valley]] all have local ordinances against exposing genitalia, but not against exposing female breasts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Women can bare it all in the Rose City|url=http://psuvanguard.com/women-can-bare-it-all-in-the-rose-city/|publisher=Vanguard|accessdate=4 September 2017|date=November 24, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Public nudity in Oregon: Where you can and can't legally be naked in the open|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/06/public_nudity_in_oregon.html/|publisher=The Oregonian|accessdate=28 December 2017|date=June 29, 2015|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817172139/http://www.oregonlive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/06/public_nudity_in_oregon.html/|archive-date=August 17, 2016}}</ref>
====Pennsylvania==== Pennsylvania laws do not directly address the issue, are ambiguous and have been used to prosecute female toplessness under open lewdness, indecent exposure or disorderly conduct.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ydr.com/story/news/2017/06/13/topl/391833001/ |title=Topless women in Pa.: Against the law? |date= June 13, 2017 |publisher= York Daily Record |accessdate=2017-11-27}}</ref>
==== Texas ==== In 1972, the Texas [[State Equal Rights Amendments|Equal Rights Amendment]] was passed into law, which communities in [[Lewisville, Texas|Lewisville, TX]]<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.feministezine.com/feminist/modern/Toplessness-A-Right.html| title=Toplessness: A Right All Women Deserve|accessdate=14 January 2010}}</ref> and [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth, TX]]<ref name=":0"/> have used to strike down gendered ordinances, including toplessness. However, women in Texas appearing topless in public can be charged under [[public nuisance]] laws,<ref name=":0"/> with the exception of [[Austin]], the state capital, where some women sunbathe topless in Zilker Park, at various festivals, and at [[Hippie Hollow]].<ref>{{cite news|url =http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,200615,00.html |title=Indecent Exposure |first=Lis |last=Wiehl|accessdate=14 January 2010 |publisher=Fox News | date=22 June 2006}}</ref> In 2013, Lewisville, TX's nudity laws were updated to indicate that food staff must wear 'decent covering'.<ref>{{Cite web|title = A Restaurant In Texas Called Redneck Heaven Was Told That Their Waitresses Had To Start Wearing Clothes|url = https://www.buzzfeed.com/ryanhatesthis/a-restaurant-in-texas-called-redneck-heaven-was-told-that-th#.xn20d4lp0|accessdate = 2015-07-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Texas town changing nudity laws to make body paint unacceptable after waitresses served customers topless|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2366237/Redneck-Heaven-naked-body-paint-waitresses-force-Texas-town-change-nudity-laws.html|accessdate = 2015-07-27}}</ref>
==== Other in United States ==== Other successful cases include: * [[District of Columbia]] (1986) <ref name=gotopless/> * [[Columbus, Ohio]] (1995) <ref name=gotopless/> * [[Moscow, Idaho]] (1998) <ref name=gotopless/> * In [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas, Nevada]], a number of hotels feature "European" pools that permit female toplessness.<ref>{{cite news|last=Yancey|first=Kitty Bean|title=Las Vegas adult and topless pools open for the season|url=http://travel.usatoday.com/destinations/lasvegas/story/2012-03-07/Las-Vegas-adult-and-topless-pools-open-for-the-season/53389122/1|accessdate=September 19, 2017|newspaper=USA Today|date=7 March 2012|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104161143/http://travel.usatoday.com/destinations/lasvegas/story/2012-03-07/Las-Vegas-adult-and-topless-pools-open-for-the-season/53389122/1|archive-date=January 4, 2014}}</ref>
== Oceania == === Australia === In [[Australia]], [[indecent exposure]] laws only refer to the genital area, so technically both male and female toplessness is legal. However, many local councils impose their own rules, and have the power to ask topless people to leave an area.<ref name=Lifehackerau>{{cite news|title=Is it legal to sunbathe topless in Australia?|date=Nov 30, 2015|access-date= Nov 12, 2018|author=Chris Jager|publisher=Lifehacker|url=https://www.lifehacker.com.au/2015/11/is-it-legal-to-sunbathe-topless/}}</ref> Additionally, women who go topless are sometimes slapped with more vague charges such as being a public nuisance, or offensive behaviour.<ref>{{cite news|title=How to Legally #FreeTheNipple in Australia|date=March 11, 2016|access-date= Nov 12, 2018|author=Katherine Gillespie|publisher=Vice.com|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_au/article/mbv4pb/how-to-legally-freethenipple-in-australia}}</ref>
On public beaches, local bylaws are not heavily enforced, and women can often sunbake topless without fuss.<ref name=Lifehackerau></ref>
Breastfeeding in public places is a legal right in Australia. Under the [[Sex Discrimination Act 1984]], no business or service provider can discriminate against a breastfeeding woman. Women can still breastfeed even if no other food/drink is allowed in the area. If a special baby care room is available for breastfeeding, women are not required to use it unless they wish to. If someone abuses a beastfeeding woman or forces her to leave, this may come under state/territory harassment laws. These protections also include women who are expressing breast milk for their baby.<ref>{{cite article|url=https://www.breastfeeding.asn.au/bf-info/breastfeeding-and-law/legalright|title=Breastfeeding in public - your legal rights|date=Aug 2016|access-date=12 Nov 2018|publisher=Australian Breastfeeding Association}}</ref>
=== New Zealand === In [[New Zealand]], there is no specific law prohibiting nudity in public places. If a person is nude ''and'' also exhibiting lewd and lascivious, or obscene behaviour, then they may fall afoul of laws.<ref>https://www.freebeaches.org.nz/legal.htm</ref>
The [[High Court of New Zealand]] has upheld a conviction of disorderly conduct for nudity in the street, because it was not a place where nudity was known to occur or commonplace. Being nude in the street is likely to incur a small fine if a complaint is made against the person, or if the person ignores a police order to cover themselves. However in practice, the likelyhood of being prosecuted for nudity on a public beach is low, providing the person keeps to themselves.<ref>https://www.freebeaches.org.nz/legal.htm</ref>
In 2012, a woman swam topless on [[Opunake]] beach. The police were called, but informed the callers that toplessness was not an offence.<ref>http://www.stuff.co.nz/taranaki-daily-news/news/6321828/Nudity-not-necessarily-an-offence</ref>
In 2017, nudists used the beach at [[Tauranga]], which causes consternation among some residents. However, the local council said there were no bylaws dealing with the issue, and that nudity was not an offence.<ref>https://www.nzherald.co.nz/front-page-top-stories/news/article.cfm?c_id=698&objectid=11824550</ref>
